title: Python to R Conversion Summary
text: Python package google-flight-analysis successfully converted R maintaining full feature parity. R package now ready use!

title: Python to R Conversion Summary
text: ✅ Parse flight data strings ✅ Extract origin/destination airports ✅ Parse departure/arrival times timezone offset support ✅ Parse prices (including comma-separated thousands) ✅ Parse number stops ✅ Parse CO2 emissions emission differences ✅ Parse flight duration ✅ Parse airline information ✅ Convert flight objects data frames

title: Python to R Conversion Summary
text: ✅ Create one-way trip queries ✅ Create round-trip queries ✅ Create chain-trip queries (multiple unrelated flights) ✅ Create perfect-chain queries (circular trips) ✅ Validate dates chronological order ✅ Validate airport codes (3 characters) ✅ Validate date formats (YYYY-MM-DD) ✅ Generate Google Flights URLs ✅ Print methods display ✅ ScrapeObjects() chromote web scraping (drivers needed!) ✅ Uses Chrome DevTools Protocol directly - reliable Selenium ✅ external driver files version compatibility issues ✅ Pre-flight checks (Chrome detection, internet connectivity) ✅ Page parsing flight data extraction ✅ Fully headless default ✅ Robust error handling detailed troubleshooting ✅ Safe resource cleanup ✅ Works Windows, macOS, Linux without additional setup

title: Python to R Conversion Summary
text: ❌ Cache functionality removed - users can save data using standard R methods like write.csv(scrape$data, "filename.csv")

text: ✅ Comprehensive tests functionality ✅ 100% pass rate ✅ Tests trip types ✅ Tests parsing logic ✅ Tests data structure creation ✅ Tests error handling

title: Python to R Conversion Summary
code: # Option 1: Source files directly source('R/flight.R') source('R/scrape.R')  # Option 2: Install from GitHub (requires devtools) devtools::install_github("rempsyc/flightanalysis")

previous_headings: How to Use the R Package
title: Python to R Conversion Summary
code: # Create a round-trip query scrape <- Scrape("JFK", "IST", "2023-07-20", "2023-08-20") print(scrape)  # Create flight objects flight1 <- Flight("2023-07-20", "JFKIST", "9:00AM", "5:00PM",                    "8 hr 0 min", "Nonstop", "$450") flight2 <- Flight("2023-07-21", "ISTCDG", "10:00AM", "2:00PM",                    "4 hr 0 min", "1 stop", "$300") flight3 <- Flight("2023-07-22", "CDGJFK", "11:00AM", "1:00PM",                    "8 hr 0 min", "Nonstop", "$500")  # Convert to data frame flights_list <- list(flight1, flight2, flight3) df <- flights_to_dataframe(flights_list)  # Save data using standard R methods write.csv(df, "flights.csv", row.names = FALSE)

title: Python to R Conversion Summary
text: Classes: Python classes → R S3 classes Data: pandas DataFrames → R data.frames Dates: Python datetime → R POSIXct Lists: Python lists → R lists (similar different indexing)

title: Python to R Conversion Summary
text: Indexing: Python [0] → R [[1]] (1-based indexing) String format: Python f-strings → R sprintf() paste() Properties: Python @property → R getter/setter pattern Methods: Python self.method() → R object$field

title: Python to R Conversion Summary
text: ScrapeObjects() function fully implemented using chromote package. Implementation details: 1. Uses Chrome DevTools Protocol (external drivers needed) 2. Automatic browser setup connection 3. Complete page scraping data extraction logic 4. Supports headless mode verbose output provides modern, driver-free web scraping solution eliminates common issues associated Selenium-based approaches.

title: Python to R Conversion Summary
text: ✅ 4 trip types (one-way, round-trip, chain, perfect-chain) ✅ Flight data parsing ✅ URL generation Google Flights ✅ Data frame conversion ✅ Caching CSV SQLite ✅ Date validation ✅ Input validation ✅ Error handling ✅ Print methods ✅ Complete test coverage ✅ Example scripts ✅ Full web scraping chromote ✅ Automatic browser driver setup ✅ Headless mode support

title: Google Flight Analysis and Scraping
text: R package analyzing, forecasting, collecting flight data prices Google Flights. Credits: package R implementation inspired original Python package google-flight-analysis Kaya Celebi.

title: Google Flight Analysis and Scraping
text: Current features include: Detailed scraping querying tools Google Flights Base analytical tools/methods price forecasting/summary Support multiple trip types: one-way, round-trip, chain-trip, perfect-chain

title: Google Flight Analysis and Scraping
text: can install development version flightanalysis GitHub:
code: # Install devtools if you haven't already # install.packages("devtools")  # Install flightanalysis devtools::install_github("rempsyc/flightanalysis") ## Using GitHub PAT from the git credential store.  ## Skipping install of 'flightanalysis' from a github remote, the SHA1 (4f4dc0b5) has not changed since last install. ##   Use `force = TRUE` to force installation

title: Google Flight Analysis and Scraping
text: main scraping function makes backbone functionalities Scrape(). serves data object, preserving flight information well meta-data query.

title: Google Flight Analysis and Scraping
code: # Create a one-way flight query scrape <- Scrape("JFK", "IST", "2025-07-20") scrape ## Scrape( {Query Not Yet Used} ## 2025-07-20: JFK --> IST ## )

title: Google Flight Analysis and Scraping
code: # Create a round-trip flight query scrape <- Scrape("JFK", "IST", "2025-07-20", "2025-08-20") scrape ## Scrape( {Query Not Yet Used} ## 2025-07-20: JFK --> IST ## 2025-08-20: IST --> JFK ## )

title: Google Flight Analysis and Scraping
text: Chain-trips defined sequence one-way flights direct relation , chronological order.
code: # Chain-trip format: origin, dest, date, origin, dest, date, ... scrape <- Scrape("JFK", "IST", "2025-08-20", "RDU", "LGA", "2025-12-25", "EWR", "SFO", "2026-01-20") scrape ## Scrape( {Query Not Yet Used} ## 2025-08-20: JFK --> IST ## 2025-12-25: RDU --> LGA ## 2026-01-20: EWR --> SFO ## )

title: Google Flight Analysis and Scraping
text: Perfect-chains defined sequence one-way flights destination previous flight origin next, origin chain final destination (cycle).
code: # Perfect-chain format: origin, date, origin, date, ..., first_origin scrape <- Scrape("JFK", "2025-09-20", "IST", "2025-09-25", "CDG", "2025-10-10", "LHR", "2025-11-01", "JFK") scrape ## Scrape( {Query Not Yet Used} ## 2025-09-20: JFK --> IST ## 2025-09-25: IST --> CDG ## 2025-10-10: CDG --> LHR ## 2025-11-01: LHR --> JFK ## )

title: Google Flight Analysis and Scraping
text: package now includes full web scraping functionality using chromote! chromote? - ✅ external driver files needed (uses Chrome DevTools Protocol directly) - ✅ reliable - driver version mismatches port conflicts - ✅ Simpler installation - just install R package - ✅ Works platforms (Windows, macOS, Linux) - ✅ Fully headless default scrape flight data Google Flights: ScrapeObjects() function : 1. Run pre-flight checks - Verify Chrome installation internet connectivity 2. Automatically connect Chrome - Using Chrome DevTools Protocol (drivers!) 3. Navigate Google Flights URLs - proper wait times page loading 4. Extract flight information - Parse prices, times, airlines, stops, emissions 5. Store results - Save data Scrape object’s data field 6. Handle errors gracefully - Provide detailed troubleshooting tips issues occur Advantages RSelenium: chromote eliminates common RSelenium issues: - ❌ “invalid assignment reference class field ‘port’” errors - ❌ driver download/installation problems - ❌ version compatibility issues - ❌ port conflicts - ✅ Just install chromote works!
code: # Create a query scrape <- Scrape("JFK", "IST", "2025-12-20", "2026-01-05")  # Scrape the data (runs in headless mode by default) scrape <- ScrapeObjects(scrape) ## Running pre-flight checks... ## [OK] Chrome/Chromium detected ## [OK] Internet connection verified ## Initializing Chrome browser... ## [OK] Browser ready ##  ## Scraping 1 object(s)... ##  ## [1/1] Processing query... ##   Query has 2 segment(s) ##   Segment 1/2: JFK -> IST on 2025-12-20 ##   Navigating to Google Flights... ##   Waiting for page content to load... ##   Retrieved 165 lines of page content ##   Parsing 165 lines of content... ##   Found 20 potential flight time markers ##   [OK] Successfully parsed 9 flights ##   Segment 2/2: IST -> JFK on 2026-01-05 ##   Navigating to Google Flights... ##   Waiting for page content to load... ##   Retrieved 164 lines of page content ##   Parsing 164 lines of content... ##   Found 20 potential flight time markers ##   [OK] Successfully parsed 9 flights ##   [OK] Total flights retrieved: 18 ##  ## Closing browser... # View the scraped data head(scrape$data) ##   departure_datetime arrival_datetime origin destination ## 1               <NA>             <NA>    IST         JFK ## 2               <NA>             <NA>    IST         JFK ## 3               <NA>             <NA>    IST         JFK ## 4               <NA>             <NA>    IST         JFK ## 5               <NA>             <NA>    IST         JFK ## 6               <NA>             <NA>    IST         JFK ##                                             airlines  travel_time price ## 1                                        593 kg CO2e 13 hr 35 min   551 ## 2 Avoids as much CO2e as 7,731 trees absorb in a day        11 hr   648 ## 3                                        479 kg CO2e 10 hr 55 min   648 ## 4                                      Other flights 10 hr 55 min   668 ## 5                                        715 kg CO2e 23 hr 25 min   552 ## 6                                        717 kg CO2e 34 hr 10 min   574 ##   num_stops         layover         access_date co2_emission_kg ## 1         1 1 hr 15 min WAW 2025-11-09 23:59:30              NA ## 2         0            <NA> 2025-11-09 23:59:30              NA ## 3         0            <NA> 2025-11-09 23:59:30              NA ## 4         0            <NA> 2025-11-09 23:59:30              NA ## 5         1 9 hr 25 min CAI 2025-11-09 23:59:30              NA ## 6         1 19 hr 5 min AMM 2025-11-09 23:59:30              NA ##   emission_diff_pct ## 1                18 ## 2               -25 ## 3                 0 ## 4                 0 ## 5                42 ## 6                43

title: Google Flight Analysis and Scraping
code: # Create Flight objects flight1 <- Flight("2025-12-25", "JFKIST", "9:00AM", "5:00PM",                    "8 hr 0 min", "Nonstop", "150 kg CO2", "10% emissions", "$450") flight2 <- Flight("2025-12-26", "ISTCDG", "10:00AM", "2:00PM",                    "4 hr 0 min", "Nonstop", "100 kg CO2", "5% emissions", "$300") flight3 <- Flight("2025-12-27", "CDGJFK", "11:00AM", "1:00PM",                    "8 hr 0 min", "1 stop", "200 kg CO2", "15% emissions", "$500")  # Convert multiple flights to a data frame flights <- list(flight1, flight2, flight3) df <- flights_to_dataframe(flights) df ##    departure_datetime    arrival_datetime origin destination airlines ## 1 2025-12-25 09:00:00 2025-12-25 17:00:00    JFK         IST       NA ## 2 2025-12-26 10:00:00 2025-12-26 14:00:00    IST         CDG       NA ## 3 2025-12-27 11:00:00 2025-12-27 13:00:00    CDG         JFK       NA ##   travel_time price num_stops layover         access_date co2_emission_kg ## 1  8 hr 0 min   450         0      NA 2025-11-09 23:59:33             150 ## 2  4 hr 0 min   300         0      NA 2025-11-09 23:59:33             100 ## 3  8 hr 0 min   500         1      NA 2025-11-09 23:59:33             200 ##   emission_diff_pct ## 1                10 ## 2                 5 ## 3                15

title: Google Flight Analysis and Scraping
text: package supports multiple trip types: One-way: Single flight origin destination Round-trip: Flight destination return Chain-trip: Sequence unrelated one-way flights chronological order Perfect-chain: Sequence destination becomes next origin, forming cycle

text: R package maintains core functionality Python version R-specific implementations: Uses S3 classes instead Python classes chromote instead Python’s selenium Base R data frames instead pandas Native R date/time handling instead Python’s datetime

title: Google Flight Analysis and Scraping
text: complete R port Python package. core data structures API fully implemented. Web scraping functionality uses chromote (Chrome DevTools Protocol), provides driver-free browser automation without configuration overhead RSelenium.

title: Create a Scrape Object — Scrape
text: Creates Scrape object representing Google Flights query. Supports one-way, round-trip, chain-trip, perfect-chain trip types.

title: Create a Scrape Object — Scrape
text: ... Arguments defining trip. Format depends trip type: - One-way: origin, dest, date - Round-trip: origin, dest, date_leave, date_return - Chain-trip: org1, dest1, date1, org2, dest2, date2, ... - Perfect-chain: org1, date1, org2, date2, ..., final_dest

title: Create a Scrape Object — Scrape
text: Scrape object (S3 class)

code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # One-way trip scrape1 <- Scrape("JFK", "BOS", "2025-12-20")  # Round-trip scrape2 <- Scrape("JFK", "YUL", "2025-12-20", "2025-12-25")  # Chain-trip scrape3 <- Scrape("JFK", "YYZ", "2025-12-20", "RDU", "LGA", "2025-12-25") } # }

title: Scrape Flight Objects — ScrapeObjects
text: Scrapes flight data Google Flights using chromote. function automatically set Chrome browser connection, navigate Google Flights URLs, extract flight information. Uses Chrome DevTools Protocol reliable, driver-free browser automation.

title: Scrape Flight Objects — ScrapeObjects
code: ScrapeObjects(objs, deep_copy = FALSE, headless = TRUE, verbose = TRUE)

title: Scrape Flight Objects — ScrapeObjects
text: objs Scrape object list Scrape objects deep_copy Logical. TRUE, returns copy objects headless Logical. TRUE, runs browser headless mode (GUI, default) verbose Logical. TRUE, shows detailed progress information (default)

title: Scrape Flight Objects — ScrapeObjects
text: Modified Scrape object(s) scraped data. **Important:** must   capture return value get scraped data: `scrape <- ScrapeObjects(scrape)`

title: Scrape Flight Objects — ScrapeObjects
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ scrape <- Scrape("JFK", "IST", "2025-12-20", "2025-12-25") scrape <- ScrapeObjects(scrape) scrape$data } # }

what: flightanalysis: Google Flight Analysis and Scraping — flightanalysis-package
title: flightanalysis: Google Flight Analysis and Scraping — flightanalysis-package
text: Tools models users analyze, forecast, collect data regarding flights prices. Features include detailed scraping querying tools Google Flights, ability store data locally SQL tables, base analytical tools/methods price forecasting/summary. package provides tools models users analyze, forecast, collect data regarding flights prices. Current features include: Detailed scraping querying tools Google Flights Support multiple trip types (one-way, round-trip, chain, perfect-chain) Base analytical tools/methods price forecasting/summary
